title: Wolyusi
author: Wolyusi
content: how to exchange bitcoin in Europe for cash?

comments.author: woez
comments.body: I think that there are several ways to exchange Bitcoins for cash in Europe. One option is to use a cryptocurrency exchange that offers fiat currency withdrawals, such as Coinbase or Kraken. This exchange allows you to sell your Bitcoins for euros or other local currency and withdraw funds to your bank account.It should be noted that exchanging Bitcoins for cash can involve risks, such as fraud or fraud. It is very important to use only reputable exchanges or platforms and make transactions with caution. You can also consider selling Bitcoins to a peer-to-peer exchange or using a cryptocurrency trading platform. However, this option may cost some technical know-how.Another option is to use a Bitcoin ATM, which allows you to sell Bitcoins for cash directly. Bitcoin ATMs can be found in many major cities across Europe, and you can find them using online directories.

comments.author: Pandji02
comments.body: There are 2 main options I think, you can use big exchanges as the safest way to do that, or you may use Bestchange, it's an aggregator of P2P, and not only exchanges where you can do that without registration, but you should be careful and precise. And read reviews before doing that.

comments.author: o_e_l_e_o
comments.body: Pick a reputable decentralized, peer-to-peer exchange from the list here: https://kycnot.me/. I suggest Bisq or RoboSats for ultimate privacy and security (although more technical), or AgoraDesk for a less technical option.Either accept an existing offer or create your own offer, using whatever fiat method you want (cash in person, cash via mail, bank transfer, etc.)Initiate the trade using the platform's in built escrow for the safety of both parties.

comments.author: ftopikit
comments.body: What country are you in? I think there is always information about exchange points in the search engine . In some such are located near the airport for the convenience of tourists.

comments.author: Porfirii
comments.body: I don't know any of them personally, but I have been talked about some Telegram channels that are used to find P2P partners for transactions in Spain. Apart from the decentralised services suggested by o_e_l_e_o, this can be another way to go if this kind of channels are also popular in your country, but let me suggest you that, although more convenient, this way can be more dangerous too.

comments.author: Wolyusi
comments.body: Quote from: Porfirii on May 22, 2023, 11:13:25 AMI don't know any of them personally, but I have been talked about some Telegram channels that are used to find P2P partners for transactions in Spain. Apart from the decentralised services suggested by o_e_l_e_o, this can be another way to go if this kind of channels are also popular in your country, but let me suggest you that, although more convenient, this way can be more dangerous too.It is better to know the tested places in advance, it is very scary to get into the wrong place. It turns out that they will throw or something.

comments.author: durop77
comments.body: In general, if you have a large profit from bitcoin, you should already cooperate with some firms to cash out money. But for example, in Turkey there are specialized exchange offices where it is enough to simply exchange crypto for cash. No problems usually arise, although there are certain difficulties, since many require either an additional commission or you can withdraw from a certain amount.

comments.author: logfiles
comments.body: Quote from: Porfirii on May 22, 2023, 11:13:25 AMI don't know any of them personally, but I have been talked about some Telegram channels that are used to find P2P partners for transactions in Spain. What a way for a noob to get quickly scammed. Telegram is a no-go zone for me for the following reasons1. Through phishing/clone telegram usernames2. No escrow service involved3. No arbitrator in case a payment dispute arises.

comments.author: Agbe
comments.body: Quote from: o_e_l_e_o on April 07, 2023, 09:37:34 AM I suggest Bisq... Is the Android version out? And if yes please can have the link for the Android version because when I tried to find out from the google search engine, this is what I saw in the search. I really want to use Bisq since last year but the desktop version is not working in my OS so I want to try the Android version. Is the above is the real website or is there another app for the Android phone?

comments.author: o_e_l_e_o
comments.body: The real websites are as follows:https://bisq.network/https://github.com/bisq-networkhttps://bisq.wiki/Main_PageThe Android app is for notifications only and must be paired with a full desktop Bisq client. The app has no functionality on its own so will be useless to you here.Why does the desktop version not work? Are you using the latest version? What OS are you using?

comments.author: DireWolfM14
comments.body: Quote from: Agbe on June 02, 2023, 11:48:06 AMI really want to use Bisq since last year but the desktop version is not working in my OS so I want to try the Android version. Is the above is the real website or is there another app for the Android phone? What you posted is not the real site, check the links posted by o_e_l_e_o.  I don't think the software will run on Win7, but it should work fine on Win10.  I've been running Win11 and Debian 11 on all my machines, and I don't have any issues running Bisq with those OSs.  I seem to recall having this discussion with you before, you're using Win7, correct?
